results.title: Liszt and his music
results.brief_description: The life of Franz Liszt, as musical composer, performer and teacher presented against a background of the European capitals where he composed and performed. Includes excerpts from the following works: Concerto No. 1 in E Flat Mojor; Hungarian Rhapsody No. 2; Sonata in B Minor and Les Preludes. Particular attention is given to the latter piece as an example of the symphonic poem.

results.title: Listening beyond words
results.creator_credit: Keith J. Atkinson, Welzel O. Whitaker and Brigham Young University
results.brief_description: At times the whole world listens for much is at stake. Many sounds compete for our attention the louder ones are often missed. Listening is essential to true communication and although 70% of our time is estimated to be spent in communication and listening takes up the bulk of that time it is often done badly. In personal relations or at work or at school, we should listen not merely for information, but also for understanding. Real listening is not passive, in the end it saves time and sometimes money.

results.title: Lilija Duks: weaver
results.creator_credit: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
Lilija Duks is a weaver who came to Australia from Latvia. In this film she talks about both her own design work and the traditional Latvian weaving that she does.

results.title: A Light in nature
results.creator_credit: Ramsay Short, Stuart Legg and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: Made on the occasion of the tercentenary of the Royal Society, this film describes the history and achievements of scientific research and indicated what may lie ahead on the borders of science. Studies on the living cell and in radio astronomy are taken as examples of fields in which significant advances may be expected in the future.

results.title: Life with junior
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “March of Time”.
A typical day in the life of a ten-year-old, presenting such common problems as the acceptance of a new brother and the refusal to eat. Emphasises the anxieties of parents over guiding their children in today’s world, and explains ways in which to cope with behaviour problems.

results.title: Life of the grasshopper
results.creator_credit: John T. Bobbitt and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Studies the structure and habits of the grasshopper and discusses its ability to survive. Compares the life cycle of other insects to that of the grasshopper. Shows the grasshopper’s structure and relates it to its ability to survive despite the perils introduced by animals and man. The life cycle of the grasshopper provides a study of incomplete metamorphosis, in contrast with the complete metamorphosis undergone by other insects.

results.title: An Ordinary half hour in the extraordinary life of Robin Beckett
results.brief_description: Produced originally for inclusion in the Melbourne University Architectural Student’s Revue, this witty satire denounces the conformity of modern urban society through the character of Robin Beckett, who lives in a rubbish bin and falls in line with other members of his social group. Reviews incidents of a day in his life. No credits available.

results.title: Letter writing at work
results.brief_description: Often the impression conveyed in a letter is very different from the one intended, and the message is muddled and confusing. This can be disastrous when a letter is written at work, or when it is sent on behalf of a company or other organisation. The film is intended to be shown to clerks, office supervisors and managers, in fact for everyone who has to write letters during their working day. It sets out to show that there is no secret art to writing effective business letters, but that there are some basic rules which can be followed in almost every case.

results.title: A Letter to Christopher
results.creator_credit: Artransa Park Studios and Kiwi Polish Company
results.brief_description: A classroom study of New Zealand’s native Kiwi - its appearance, habits and ancestry. It has been closely protected since 1908: its export is prohibited except on rare occasions, and it may only be kept in captivity for scientific studies. it has become a national emblem appearing on coins, incorporated in badges, and commonly used in referring to New Zealand’s people. Told by an Australian girl, Susan Boyden.

results.title: A Letter to Amy
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Freitag, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: Tells the story of Peter, a young African American boy, who is planning his birthday party. Shows him pondering over the invitation letter and then anxiously awaiting the party day to see if she comes. Concludes with Amy arriving very late, thus making the party a happy one.
